data.title: Cannot run node.js app through debugger tab
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.3.0-insider (1.3.0-insider) (6bc81df453ab2156d2630fbb89ad7d0c80620420)
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.5 

Steps to Reproduce:

Trying to launch a Node JS app give an error:  Cannot launch debug target (spawn node ENOENT).

Using Homebrew installed Nodejs (path to node command is /usr/local/bin/node)

The bash login path, which contains /usr/local/bin, does not seem to be included when trying to run the app.

Launch.json contains:

```
{
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "name": "Launch",
            "type": "node",
            "request": "launch",
            "program": "${workspaceRoot}/nodeapp/server.js",
            "stopOnEntry": false,
            "args": [],
            "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
            "runtimeExecutable": null,
            "runtimeArgs": [
                "--nolazy"
            ],
            "env": {
                "NODE_ENV": "development"
            },
            "externalConsole": false,
            "sourceMaps": false,
            "outDir": null
        },
        {
            "name": "Attach",
            "type": "node",
            "request": "attach",
            "port": 5858,
            "sourceMaps": false,
            "outDir": null,
            "localRoot": "${workspaceRoot}",
            "remoteRoot": null
        }
    ]
}
```

data.title: take advantage of tsserver model of code for faster TypeScript builds

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2
- OS Version: Windows 7, x64

Currently a way to build a TypeScript project is to run a console command (tsc) that works separately from the tsserver. It looks like the the build could have been done faster if the model of code stored in the tsserver was used that is already parsed, bound and partially typechecked.

data.title: npm command prompt  working  now
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.2.0
- OS Version:win10 10240

Steps to Reproduce:
1. open vscode and  change workspace setting 

`
    // The path of the shell that the terminal uses on Windows.
`
`
    "terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "C:\\windows\\system32\\cmd.exe",
`
to 
`
    "terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "C:\\Windows\\System32\\cmd.exe /k 'C:\\Program Files\\nodejs\\nodevars.bat'",
`
1.  use `ctrl+'`'`

data.title: Rename provider should support to 'resolve' rename location (to expand, invalidate, etc)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

I’m having trouble with getting VS Code to do a rename operation correctly. When I put the caret on the word I want to rename and I hit F2, I see this:

![badrename](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7052303/15866856/50c279ec-2c95-11e6-994a-1e059dfe2a43.png)

However, if I do the same operation (F2) on a simple string, I get just the contents I expect:

![goodrename](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7052303/15866859/57f6efcc-2c95-11e6-9891-c39dc2498e2c.png)

data.title: Request toggle for bottom-docked view to be side-docked or a column
data.body: It would be nice if the bottom-docked pane (integrated terminal, Output view, etc.) could optionally appear as a column alongside the editors, instead of docked to the bottom. My team has a command-line test watcher and node server that we keep an eye on while developing. Our terminal output tends to be tall and narrow. A column view or side-docked view would fit better and not cover vertical space of the editors.

data.title: find/replace "Find in selection" is disabled when only one line selected
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.2.0
- OS Version:Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Use Ctrl+F or Ctrl+H to run the Find or Replace commands
2. Select something on one line.
   The "Find in selection" toggle is disabled:
   ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7274059/15865175/0329d804-2c97-11e6-9cc6-aa9d0d4105db.png)

_Note: it works when selecting multiple lines, but the replacement does not adhere to the selection, but rather the lines selected; e.g. if you select the first half of a line, the replacement will replace parts in the entire line_

data.title: Find all references does not show references to imports
data.body:
Version 1.2.0-insider
Commit 7ccb21d7e7256a7d42f3dda8b2d3721b8e59724f
Date 2016-05-30T12:59:38.593Z
Shell 0.37.6
Renderer 49.0.2623.75
Node 5.10.0

Steps to Reproduce:

```
foo.ts
export enum X {  A, B, C}

bar.ts
import foo = require("foo");

module Main {
    import X = foo.X;
}
```
1.  Click on the word foo on line 1 of bar.ts
2. Press Shift + F12 to get all references

EXPECTED: it shows the import as an usage of foo
ACTUAL: it doesn't show any usage and seems like it is unused in bar.ts

- OS Version: 8.1

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open first window and standard working folder.
2. File -> new window
3. Second window opens with blank workspace; attempt to select same working folder as first window. Folder does not open in second window.

data.title: Output pane is a performance bottleneck once it gets big enough
data.body:
I started self hosting on the output pane, keeping it visible at all times. I feel the workbench getting super sluggish after 15 minutes of smooth development. I feel it while typing: it becomes slow. Clearing the output from the Output pane fixes it.

In the following screenshots / timelines, I merely enter a newline and wait for the workbench to react and update all decorations.
#### Before

When the output is really big (after 15 minutes of development) this is what I get:

[Chrome timeline](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/302815/before-clear.json.txt)

![screen shot 2016-06-07 at 16 23 30](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22350/15861232/397690fc-2ccc-11e6-944d-20f85ad589e5.png)
#### After

Once I clear the output, all of the sluggishness disappears.

[Chrome timeline](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/302818/after-clear.json.txt)

![screen shot 2016-06-07 at 16 25 12](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22350/15861342/6ba433cc-2ccc-11e6-8917-891d418d7a85.png)

data.title: CompletionItems should control if they are auto acceptable
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.1-insider
- OS Version: Ubuntu 14.04 LTS

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Type any word that conflicts with one of your variable, for example if you have a variable CustomerComponent and you want to have a comment saying "this is the problem with my Customer." when you start typing Customer the CustomerComponent will popup and when you want to insert a period it will auto complete with CustomerComponent

I come across similar behavior when typing import statement like

```
import {CustomerComponent} from '/widget/customer.model.ts'
```

Intellisense will try to autocomplete again in when I type "customer.". There the only two instance when this happen, and it seems to happen quite often. I would suggest to switch Intellisense to spellcheck in a comment and perhaps turn it off on import, or have an option where a period wouldn't trigger autocomplete. I'm not too sure about how best to address the import case. The comment case seem to be clearer to have a spellcheck mode, or just simply turn it off if there's no built-in spellcheck.

data.title: Debugger "crashes"
data.body:
vscode-php-debug stopped working after VS Code 1.2, see https://github.com/felixfbecker/vscode-php-debug/issues/39. The debug section and breakpoint markers disappear after the second step over. The requests send by the adapter seem to be completely fine though:

``` js
-> nextRequest
{ type: 'request',
  seq: 13,
  command: 'next',
  arguments: { threadId: 1 } }
<- outputEvent
OutputEvent {
  seq: 0,
  type: 'event',
  event: 'output',
  body: { category: 'stdout', output: 'hello' } }
hello
<- stoppedEvent
StoppedEvent {
  seq: 0,
  type: 'event',
  event: 'stopped',
  body: { reason: 'step', threadId: 1, allThreadsStopped: false } }
<- nextResponse
Response {
  seq: 0,
  type: 'response',
  request_seq: 13,
  command: 'next',
  success: true,
  body: { allThreadsContinued: false } }
-> threadsRequest
{ type: 'request', seq: 14, command: 'threads' }
<- threadsResponse
Response {
  seq: 0,
  type: 'response',
  request_seq: 14,
  command: 'threads',
  success: true,
  body: { threads: [ Thread { id: 1, name: 'Request 1 (3:17:24 PM)' } ] } }
-> stackTraceRequest
{ type: 'request',
  seq: 15,
  command: 'stackTrace',
  arguments: { threadId: 1, startFrame: 0, levels: 20 } }
<- stackTraceResponse
Response {
  seq: 0,
  type: 'response',
  request_seq: 15,
  command: 'stackTrace',
  success: true,
  body: 
   { stackFrames: 
      [ StackFrame {
          id: 2,
          source: 
           Source {
             name: 'hello_world.php',
             path: 'C:\\Users\\felix\\git\\OpenSource\\vscode-php-debug\\testproject\\hello_world.php',
             sourceReference: 0 },
          line: 4,
          column: 1,
          name: '{main}' } ] } }
-> scopesRequest
{ type: 'request',
  seq: 16,
  command: 'scopes',
  arguments: { frameId: 2 } }
<- scopesResponse
Response {
  seq: 0,
  type: 'response',
  request_seq: 16,
  command: 'scopes',
  success: true,
  body: 
   { scopes: 
      [ Scope { name: 'Locals', variablesReference: 4, expensive: false },
        Scope { name: 'Superglobals', variablesReference: 5, expensive: false },
        Scope {
          name: 'User defined constants',
          variablesReference: 6,
          expensive: false } ] } }
-> variablesRequest
{ type: 'request',
  seq: 17,
  command: 'variables',
  arguments: { variablesReference: 4 } }
<- variablesResponse
Response {
  seq: 0,
  type: 'response',
  request_seq: 17,
  command: 'variables',
  success: true,
  body: { variables: [] } }
```

VS Code just doesnt display anything anymore. Could it have something todo with the async events? Sometimes events are sent in between a request and a response

@weinand

data.title: Terminal Bug: When running 'zsh', terminal window is cut off on scroll
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: OS X El Capitan 10.11.5

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open terminal in VS Code and run a long, scrollable command
2. Scroll terminal window up and see that it stays where it should
3. Run `zsh` and then try to scroll terminal window
4. See the terminal window jump to the left and get cut off.

Closing the terminal window and opening it back up again, solves the issue. Also, running without extensions still makes the bug appear.
![vscodeterminalbug-](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6547112/15858732/0c306b0e-2c90-11e6-95f4-b95bd6c8a744.gif)

- OS Version: WIndows 7 Enterprise

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Run grunt watchify on a javascript project .
2. Modify the Js flie, so only new changes is built, the entire title area starts flickering, if you do in new Terminal addition that comes with latest VSCode, it makes it look like its on oveer drive, its also as if it's constantly building.

Very strange

data.title: Cannot jump to file from Integrated Terminal
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2
- OS Version: OS X

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open the terminal and make a compilation error in your favorite language
2. Click on the file name it won't jump to the chosen file.

```
--> Monitor: Files changed, Building...
go build -v -i
github.com/REDACTED/REDACTED-ms/REDACTED
REDACTED/crumb.go:223: undefined: rpcCall
```

When selecting and clicking on `REDACTED/crumb.go:223` it won't jump to the file.

Check how iTerm2 and ACME addresses this issue.

data.title: An option to hide the side bar when it's toggled
data.body:
The **Toggle Sidebar** action only _minimizes_ the sidebar.  It would be really nice to get an option to completely hide the sidebar when it's toggled.

Sometimes I use it but most of the time I do not, and it just takes up space.

A user setting named, for example, `hideSidebarWhenToggled` would be perfect.

data.title: On mac ctrl-n should behave exactly like DownArrow
data.body: The same is true for ctrl-p and UpArrow. This fixes that
